I‚Äôm honestly shocked I never played this game earlier.
The moment the first episode started, the art style hit me ‚Äî it looks like a living comic book, and it‚Äôs beautiful. The characters feel real, the voice acting is amazing, and the story makes you forget that you‚Äôre even playing a game.

I went in expecting a zombie game‚Ä¶but this is really a human story.
The choices actually matter. I found myself pausing, thinking about what to say, because every decision feels important. It‚Äôs less about shooting and more about surviving, trusting, protecting, and caring.

By the end of Episode 1, I was completely attached to the characters.
If you love story-driven games, emotional moments, and decisions that stick with you ‚Äî this is a masterpiece. Absolutely worth every rupee and every minute.

The Walking Dead: The Telltale Definitive Series Review ‚Äî 11/10 (Emotional Damage Simulator)

The Walking Dead: The Telltale Definitive Series isn‚Äôt just a game‚Äîit‚Äôs an emotional rollercoaster designed specifically to destroy your heart, rebuild it, and then shatter it again for good measure. It‚Äôs a storytelling masterpiece that grabs you by the soul and refuses to let go, long after the credits roll.

Across all four seasons, you follow Clementine‚Äîone of the greatest characters in gaming history‚Äîthrough a world where every choice matters, every decision haunts you, and every friendship feels fragile and precious. The writing is phenomenal, the performances are unforgettable, and the relationships you build feel real. You don‚Äôt just play this game‚Äîyou live it.

The Definitive Series brings updated graphics, improved lighting, developer commentary, and all the DLC in one package, making it the best way to experience the full journey. The visual upgrades make the art style even more striking, and the preserved documentary-style extras give fans a deeper look into the incredible work behind the scenes.

And oh boy‚Äîthe decisions. No other game makes you pause the screen for five agonizing minutes while you question your morality, your intelligence, and your entire existence. The pressure is real. The tears are real. The trauma is real.

If you think you‚Äôre emotionally strong, The Walking Dead will prove you wrong.

Pros

Storytelling at its absolute peak

Deep, unforgettable characters‚Äîespecially Clementine and Lee

Meaningful choices with serious emotional weight

Gorgeous updated visuals and a complete collection in one place

A soundtrack that will ruin you (in the best way)

Cons

You‚Äôll cry. A lot. Like, multiple times. Maybe daily.

Permanent emotional damage (but worth it)

Final Verdict:
A masterpiece of narrative gaming that delivers some of the most powerful storytelling ever created. If you finish without crying, check your pulse.

The Walking Dead: The Telltale Series is a truly emotional masterpiece in the world of interactive gaming. Its strong narrative, memorable characters, and tense moral choices immerse the player in the merciless world of zombies in a way that is rarely seen. The game successfully combines a dramatic story with engaging interactive gameplay, creating an experience that lingers long in the mind. I played The Walking Dead Telltale Series expecting a powerful story and meaningful choices. What I got instead was something that felt more like a chore than a game. Even after all these years, the technical issues are still everywhere. The animation looks stiff, the graphics feel like an oil painting filter pasted on top of everything, and the facial expressions are so awkward that they end up looking funny in scenes that are supposed to be serious. The bugs never stopped either, from weird character movements to broken achievements, and they killed any sense of immersion the game tried to build.

Fans will say, "It is old, you have to look past the flaws." And? A buggy game is still a buggy game. Age does not magically excuse poor execution, especially when the whole experience relies on storytelling and emotion. When the presentation constantly breaks the mood, the impact is gone.

The biggest disappointment for me was the ‚Äúchoices matter‚Äù idea. I went in expecting my decisions to shape the story, but it quickly became clear that nothing I picked actually changed anything important. The major events happen no matter what. You can slightly shift relationships or delay a character‚Äôs death, but the outcome is always the same. After a while, it felt like the game was just taking my opinions and giving me nothing in return. I could not even skip dialogue, so every slow scene dragged on.

Now for the story, because that is the one thing people praise the game for. It is fine. Not amazing, not groundbreaking, just fine. It is one long sad journey where people die around you and there is nothing you can do to change it. Some characters are decent, but most of them felt forgettable to me, and the voice acting did not help. I never connected to anyone the way players said I would.

I finished Season 1, but it was a struggle. The gameplay is basically clicking around and picking dialogue options, the pacing feels slow, and nothing I chose felt meaningful. The Walking Dead Telltale Series ends up being interactive cinema that tries to pretend it is a choice-driven game. My brief opinion is simple: I do not like it, and it was not worth playing.

My brief opinion about this game: I don't like it. The whole game is one long sad story where your ‚Äúcomrades‚Äù die and there's nothing you can do about it.

Obviously, the game has its advantages. Here's what I liked:
‚Ä¢    Beautiful graphics
‚Ä¢    Interesting storyline
‚Ä¢    The ability to interact with the surrounding world
‚Ä¢    Good musical accompaniment

But honestly, I expected that in a game with ‚Äúchoices matter,‚Äù my decisions would influence the plot and the ending. I was wrong. In the game, most of the important events happen regardless of the decisions made by the player. With their decisions, the player can either improve/ruin relationships with characters, or delay their deaths. I would say this game is simply interactive cinema.

The second major drawback of the game is the excessive amount of violence, which is very unpleasant to watch. Severed limbs, cannibalism, child abuse, scenes where people are eaten alive‚Äîthese are just the tip of the iceberg. Murders, corpses in the streets, walking rotting dead, and constant quarrels are the norm in this game. If you're not a sadist, such scenes will leave you with unpleasant feelings.

And the last serious drawback of this game, which I have already mentioned, is that the entire game is permeated with a sense of despair and hopelessness. The main characters' companions literally die in every episode, no matter what you do. Due to a lack of food, water, medicine, and shelter, people turn into animals, ready to kill and rob anyone, and there is constant fighting. Those who survive the struggle for resources often envy those who have already died, and the survivors often have suicidal thoughts. Of course, there are pleasant moments in the game: walks in nature, communication with friends, moments of fun ‚Äî but there are far fewer of them than negative ones.

My rating for the game is 2/5.
This game is a safe purchase for anyone who appreciates visually stunning interactive cinema with a focus on violence and despair.

I played The Walking Dead Telltale Series expecting a powerful story and meaningful choices. What I got instead was something that felt more like a chore than a game. Even after all these years, the technical issues are still everywhere. The animation looks stiff, the graphics feel like an oil painting filter pasted on top of everything, and the facial expressions are so awkward that they end up looking funny in scenes that are supposed to be serious. The bugs never stopped either, from weird character movements to broken achievements, and they killed any sense of immersion the game tried to build.

Fans will say, "It is old, you have to look past the flaws." And? A buggy game is still a buggy game. Age does not magically excuse poor execution, especially when the whole experience relies on storytelling and emotion. When the presentation constantly breaks the mood, the impact is gone.

The biggest disappointment for me was the ‚Äúchoices matter‚Äù idea. I went in expecting my decisions to shape the story, but it quickly became clear that nothing I picked actually changed anything important. The major events happen no matter what. You can slightly shift relationships or delay a character‚Äôs death, but the outcome is always the same. After a while, it felt like the game was just taking my opinions and giving me nothing in return. I could not even skip dialogue, so every slow scene dragged on.

Now for the story, because that is the one thing people praise the game for. It is fine. Not amazing, not groundbreaking, just fine. It is one long sad journey where people die around you and there is nothing you can do to change it. Some characters are decent, but most of them felt forgettable to me, and the voice acting did not help. I never connected to anyone the way players said I would.

I finished Season 1, but it was a struggle. The gameplay is basically clicking around and picking dialogue options, the pacing feels slow, and nothing I chose felt meaningful. The Walking Dead Telltale Series ends up being interactive cinema that tries to pretend it is a choice-driven game. My brief opinion is simple: I do not like it, and it was not worth playing.

My brief opinion about this game: I don't like it. The whole game is one long sad story where your ‚Äúcomrades‚Äù die and there's nothing you can do about it.

Obviously, the game has its advantages. Here's what I liked:
‚Ä¢    Beautiful graphics
‚Ä¢    Interesting storyline
‚Ä¢    The ability to interact with the surrounding world
‚Ä¢    Good musical accompaniment

But honestly, I expected that in a game with ‚Äúchoices matter,‚Äù my decisions would influence the plot and the ending. I was wrong. In the game, most of the important events happen regardless of the decisions made by the player. With their decisions, the player can either improve/ruin relationships with characters, or delay their deaths. I would say this game is simply interactive cinema.

The second major drawback of the game is the excessive amount of violence, which is very unpleasant to watch. Severed limbs, cannibalism, child abuse, scenes where people are eaten alive‚Äîthese are just the tip of the iceberg. Murders, corpses in the streets, walking rotting dead, and constant quarrels are the norm in this game. If you're not a sadist, such scenes will leave you with unpleasant feelings.

And the last serious drawback of this game, which I have already mentioned, is that the entire game is permeated with a sense of despair and hopelessness. The main characters' companions literally die in every episode, no matter what you do. Due to a lack of food, water, medicine, and shelter, people turn into animals, ready to kill and rob anyone, and there is constant fighting. Those who survive the struggle for resources often envy those who have already died, and the survivors often have suicidal thoughts. Of course, there are pleasant moments in the game: walks in nature, communication with friends, moments of fun ‚Äî but there are far fewer of them than negative ones.

My rating for the game is 2/5.
This game is a safe purchase for anyone who appreciates visually stunning interactive cinema with a focus on violence and despair.
